Award.AwardTitle: Smart and Connected Health Principal Investigator Workshop 2014: From Discovery to Dissemination and Implementation Research

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Smart and Connected Health Principal Investigator Workshop 2014: From Discovery to Dissemination and Implementation Research

This proposal supports the NSF Smart and Connected Health (SCH) principal investigators meeting in Arlington, VA in August 2014. The meeting brings together principal investigators of projects awarded by the Smart and Connected Health program during 2011, 2012 and 2013. The SCH program was setup in order to bridge gaps in fundamental science and engineering necessary to transform health and healthcare in accordance with the with recent PCAST reports (2010), as well as to be focused on prevention and person-centered care. In particular, the workshop addresses a wider range of challenges in advancing health with foundational research from the computer science, engineering and the social, behavioral and economic disciplines. An objective of the workshop is to provide an opportunity for the principal investigators to explore research progress in a diverse set of funded projects and discuss important current issues, as well as future challenges associated with research in transdisciplinary scientific areas. The discussions will be supported by projects-related posters and further stimulated by a number of invited speakers in relevant fields that will explore the scientific frameworks in moving findings from discovery to dissemination and implementation research. It is anticipated that the meeting will stimulate discussions, connections, and collaborations that will facilitate progress in the area of Smart and Connected Health.

The workshop should have a significant impact on the participants and the future of the Smart and Connected Health program (SCH). The focus of the workshop is on the science of discovery through dissemination and implementation research. The workshop results are likely to include new research directions that will be publicized to the research community through publications and a workshop website. The results dissemination should inform and the developing Smart and Connected Health research community in their transdisciplinary collaboration, educational activities, and spur other innovative research directions. The broader impacts of the workshop are to facilitate progress in the field and stimulate conversations, connections, and collaborations that will lead toward better informed and effective smart and connected health research and resulting technologies for the broadest possible user populations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant provided funding for a workshop for Principal Investigators of NSF grants from the Smart and Connected Health (SCH) program. This 1.5 day meeting with 124 registered attendees was held in Arlington, VA to identify research, training, and commercialization needs that should be addressed in the future of this initiative.

In addition to keynote presentations by prominent industry and research leaders and panels by key personnel at relevant government organizations, there were two poster sessions providing participants a chance to present their research progress to date and to review the posters of other researchers to make connections to possible collaborators. A publicly facing website and was created to connect participants and provide resources both before and after the meeting.

Several breakout sessions were held on the second day with the aim of soliciting input from participants on the main issues confronting the field of SCH. Through a series of conference calls, email exchanges, surveys of participants, and an open Google document, meeting planners identified breakout session topics they considered as most important and chose leaders for each based upon their expertise. A main group report back facilitated discussion amongst the larger on the key topics, and notes were published and shared with all attendees and made available via the meeting's website.

The meeting organizers prepared a final written report summarizing the recommendations of the meeting attendees for future needs and priority areas in the area of Smart & Connected Health. The success of the meeting was evaluated with a post-meeting survey to attendees, with a large majority of the participants finding the experience highly valuable or valuable.

The intellectual merit includes a reflection on the field of smart and connected health and identification of future research directions and needs for progress in this space.

The broader impacts include the connection of researchers to facilitate future collaborations and resource sharing and dissemination of avenues for primary investigators to commercialize and transfer the results of funded research for maximum impact.


Last Modified: 06/12/2015
Modified by: Julie A Kientz
